contents.text: Fiona the Chef Flamingo and the Case of Missing Carrots
Do you want to know what's going to happen next?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
"I'm going to get the carrots," said Fiona the Chef Flamingo.

It is an important morning for Fiona. She is inviting her friends to her restaurant. She will need to make appetizers, entrees, and desserts for twelve guests. Her friend, George the Hippo helps her cook the dinner.

The carrots will be the main dish because Fiona likes the bright orange color and the sweet taste.

"Yum yum, the carrots cooked with butter and lemon will be very yummy!" said Fiona.

But Fiona doesn’t expect the problem with that she is going to deal with.
The carrots are gone!

They were there fifteen minutes ago, but now they are nowhere to be found.

She looks up over the shelves, down under the table, and the bowls where she made the sides. But the carrots are nowhere to be found.

"George, do you know where the carrots are?" Fiona asked George who is preparing the mushroom sauce.

"The carrots are exactly where you are right now ..." says George.

But then, George sees something across the kitchen's window that caught his attention.

"Fiona, what is that thing with the brown cloak carrying a bag full of carrots?" asks George.

He points his finger to the mysterious figure on the garden.

"George! That's the carrot thief!" shouts Fiona.

She tries to fly to get out of the window. But, Fiona being a young flamingo, can't fly very high. She falls off to the floor.

George, being a good friend, grabbed a bench and put it under the window.

"Thank you George!" says Fiona. She then flies through the window towards the carrot thief.

George watches Fiona's heroic act from the kitchen with complete amazement.
As Fiona flies, she grabs the bag full of carrots.

She lands safely to the soft lawn with her carrots.

 The day is saved.
But the carrot thief quickly escaped and he or she is nowhere to be seen.
Can you tell a story when you were trying a new activity that was hard at first?
contents.subtext: Any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath like running, playing in the park, dancing, and swimming.

contents.text: Can you think about anything that can make the activity easier to do?

Being active doesn't have to be hard.

Try finding a comfortable place to be active or finding adults and friends that can help you to be active.
Chapter 2
Do you want to know what's going to happen with the Fiona and the carrots?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
Fiona is relieved that she get her carrots back. George is also very happy!

"Fiona, that was awesome!" says George.

"You helped too!" says Fiona.

As they walk back to the kitchen, they heard a loud yell from the house next door.

"My carrots!" 

It is Ms. Dole’s voice. Fiona and George look at each other.

Fiona and George run toward Ms. Dole's backyard to find the old doe looking very worried.

"Somebody steals my carrots!" says Ms. Dole when she sees Fiona and George.

"We can help you find the carrots!" says George.

"That's right! George and I can help you catch the thing that took the carrots!" says Fiona.

So Fiona and George run and follow the footmarks of the thing that took the carrots.

"I think it’s a big cat," says Fiona.

"No way it's a cat. Cats don't eat carrots, Fiona," replies George.

"I have a cousin who lives with a cat. Cousin Cluck. Her roommate, Pipi, loves carrot! I like Pipi, she's a lot of fun. So I think the thing that took the carrots could be a cat!" explains Fiona before she will be totally surprised.
George is no longer by her side!

George is so tired of running. He is several feet behind from Fiona.

"George, are you okay?" asks Fiona."I'm okay Fiona. It's just I can't walk very fast," says George who is out of breath.

"You go first, and I will catch up with you," says George.

"George, I can't do this without you. Let’s run a little slower so you can run as fast as me. The carrot thief's footmark will not go anywhere soon," says Fiona.

George feels uplifted by what Fiona says.

"Okay! Let's catch this carrot thief!" says George.

So they run and follow the footmarks on the ground. They run a little slower, but it doesn't matter because Fiona prefers to do it with George.

Then they saw a suspicious figure standing by an ice cream truck.

This figure is not very tall. Just like the thing that took the carrots. Wearing a brown coat. Just like the thing that took the carrots.

"Fiona, I think it's the thief," says George.

"Let's catch him," says Fiona.

BAM!

Fiona jumps over the figure with the coat. Then George jumps over Fiona and the figure with the coat!
Can you tell a time when you thought physical activity was hard?
contents.subtext: Physical activity means any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath like running, playing on the playground, or playing sports like baseball or soccer.

contents.text: Fiona encouraged George to run and be active. Can you think of people who can help you to be active?
Having a helping hand can make physical activity more doable.
Chapter 3
Do you think Fiona and George caught the thing that took the carrots?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
Fiona jumps over the figure with the coat. And George jumps over Fiona and the figure with the coat.

They thought it was the thing that took the carrots. But it was not...

It is Mr. Racoon!

 He just ordered a pumpkin ice cream cone that looks like a piece of carrot from afar.

"I'm sorry Mr. Racoon. We are chasing the carrot thief. I thought you were the carrot thief!" says Fiona.

"That's ok," says Mr. Racoon. "Turns out I don't like this ice cream flavor anyway."

"But I did saw a mysterious figure carrying a bag full of carrots," says Mr. Racoon as he points his finger to the other end of the street.

"I don’t think we can catch the carrot thief," says Fiona. She is a little upset.

"Yeah, the carrot thief is very sneaky," says George who is just as upset.

"You kids don’t give up!" says Ms. Dole.

Then Ms. Dole says, “Let’s set up a plan to catch the carrot thief.”

Fiona, George, and Ms. Dole huddle and talk about their plan.

After several minutes of talking about their plans, they pick one plan that will work best.

"I like this plan!" says George.

"This is a plan that I like!" says Ms. Dole.

"We have a plan then!" says Fiona.

They feel more sure that they can catch the thing that took the carrots now that they have a plan.
Can you think of a plan to be physically active with your family this week? Pick a time, place, and the activities you want to do.
contents.subtext: Physical activities are any activities that makes you sweat or become out of breath like doing yoga, jumping rope, or skating.

contents.text: Tell me how it made you feel knowing that you have a plan to be active?
It is sometimes helpful to plan activities before you do them!
Chapter 4
Do you think Fiona's plan will work?
contents.subtext: To read the rest of the story, complete a one-day challenge with your family.

contents.text:
The plan is as follows. Fiona, George, and Ms. Dole set up a trap for the carrot thief.

That trap is a king-size blanket and a bucketful of molasses.

To attract the thief, they put Fiona's carrots on the floor. If the thief is trying to steal the carrot, George will pour a bucketful of molasses to the thief. Then Fiona will throw the blanket

"This is a perfect plan!" says George.

"I think it is," says Fiona.

Then they hear something.

 "Chomp-chomp-comp..."

 "It must be the carrot thief!" whispers Fiona

George quickly grabs the bucket full of molasses. He is about to throw the molasses at the thing that is eating the carrots.

The chomp-chomp-chomp sound does not come from the carrot thief. It is Ms. Dole eating the carrots!

"Ms. Dole! Why do you eat the carrots?" asks Fiona who is slightly irritated.

 "Sorry, Fiona. I'm very hungry. I haven't had breakfast yet. The bad carrot thief stole my carrots," says Ms. Dole.

 "Ms. Dole, you have a little bit of the carrots, but we must wait a couple more minutes. We want to catch the carrot thief so you can have your carrots back for breakfast," says Fiona.

 Ms. Dole agrees.

They waited a couple of minutes before a figure wearing a cloak walks towards the carrots. The carrots that are set as a trap.

This figure quietly walk. 

Step by step. Very slowly. Then the claws hands emerge to grab the carrots.

George throws the bucketful of molasses. 

Fiona throws the king-sized blanket. 

Ms. Dole is about to jump over the blanket.

The molasses covers the thing that took the carrots. Then the blanket fell over the thing and sticks. The thing that took the carrots can barely move.

 "We got the thief!" exclaims George.

They do not expect the thing that took the carrots to be someone they know. 

It is Mr. Fox!

"Mr. Fox! Why did you steal our carrots!" yells Fiona.

Mr. Fox feels really sorry for taking the carrots without permission.

 "I really like carrots! But I am too embarrassed to buy one myself because foxes don't eat carrots!" says Mr. Fox. 

There was a brief silence.

"Oh, Mr. Fox. You should not be embarrassed to eat carrots. 

 "Vegetables are good for your body. There is nothing embarrassing about being healthy," says George.

 "And you should not let other people tells you who you are!" says Fiona.

"But Mr. Fox, you should be embarrassed about yourself because you steal carrots from other people," yells Ms. Dole.

 "I'm really sorry. I should not steal anything from other people. I just want to eat carrots,” says Mr. Fox.

"We will accept your apology if you help Fiona prepare her dinner party tonight." says Ms. Dole sternly.

Later that night, Mr. Fox helps Fiona washes the dishes for the party. 

It was a lot of dishes.

Fiona also taught Mr. Fox the many ways to prepare carrots. Fiona’s guests enjoy the dishes she prepared. They like the carrots because of the bright orange color and the sweet taste.

Fiona is happy that the dinner party went well. But most importantly, she's happy that she can solve the mystery of missing carrots with her friend George.
Can you think about a physical activity that your Mom/Dad/Caregiver enjoy doing together with you?
contents.subtext: Being active means doing any activity that makes you sweat or become out of breath. For example, running, playing in the park, dancing, swimming.

contents.text: Why do you think your Mom/Dad/Caregiver enjoy doing that activity with you.
Physical activity can make you feel tired. But if you do it with your family, it can be a lot of fun.
